title: Ghana: EPA Descends On Adamus Resources
text:

The meeting had been called by the EPA, following a complaint submitted to it by the chief and people of Anwia, including the Member of Parliament (MP) for the area, Emmanuel Armah Kofi Buah, over the negative impact the mining activities of Adamus Resource was having on the people. 
Information available to The Chronicle indicates that the regulatory body gave a period of 
two weeks for which the mining company was to sit with the chiefs to negotiate on possible relocation exercise, after which it would send its report to the regulatory body. 
It would be recalled that the EPA and the Ellembele District Security Council (DISEC) jointly closed down the blasting site of Adamus Resources, following complaints of the negative impact the blasting was having on the people. 
Buildings in the village developed cracks, whilst the electrical gadgets being used by the people were destroyed as a result of blasting carried out by the mining company. This sordid development forced the people to protest, including an attempt to lynch their chief for reportedly supporting the mining company. 
The development compelled the MP of the area, Emmanuel Armah Kofi Buah to visit the site of the mining company, after which he lodged a formal complaint with the EPA over the proximity of the blasting site and it accompanying negative effect on his constituents. 
Some of the residents confided in The Chronicle that had it not been the intervention of the MP, EPA would have sat idle without doing anything about the situation. 
According to them, they have sent countless petitions to the regulatory body but they failed to act upon them, but immediately they received a petition from the MP, experts were sent to the blasting site who recommended the closure of the place. 
The EPA then went ahead to fix the 22nd of July for all the stakeholders to meet and discuss the issue. 
The meeting was attended by management team of Adamus Resource, led by Mr. Mark Addo, the Finance Director of the company, the regional Minister, Pal Evans Aidoo, Ellembelle District Chief Executive (DCE), Daniel Eshun and the MP himself. 
The Mineral Commission Boss, Dr. Toni Aubyn and that of the EPA, including another Minister were also present. The Chronicle sources at the meeting told this reporter that the EPA maintained their position on the closure of the mining company blasting site. However, it ordered it to undertake its blasting in another site instead of the old site. 
The EPA and the Mineral Commission according to the meeting would commission an independent body to ascertain the destruction caused to the buildings and properties as a result of the mining company's blasting activities. 
The Chief of Anwia, Nana Simanle Kpanyle who confirmed the decision of the meeting told this reporter in a telephone interview that the management of the mining company apologized to the meeting for the harm caused them (indigenes), as a result of their blasting activities and promised to reduce its severity. 
But Nana Simale Kpanyile said he objected on grounds that the community could not take their word. For now, what the community wants is relocation as agreed at the meeting. "So we are looking forward to Adamus coming to negotiate with us in two weeks time as the meeting directed". 
Nana told this reporter that though they were not against the mining company operation, they could, however, not sit down unconcerned for the activities of the mining company to destroy their livelihood. 
The MP on his part thanked the EPA and the Mineral Commission for the swift response it handled the case. 
Mr. Armah Buah expressed the hope that the mining company would act on the orders of the EPA and the Mineral Commission to ensure peace in the area. Ghana
